## Dallas, Texas, Proposition A, Changes to City Employee Retirement Fund Measure (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter 40A of the Dallas City Code, known as the employees’ retirement fund of the City of Dallas, be amended in accordance with Ordinance No. 32801 to: add, revise, and delete various definitions; provide amended terms and term limits of the board; modify the retirement fund board’s powers and duties; specify the date the board shall adopt the actuarially determined contribution rate, the current total adjusted total obligation rate, the current total obligation rate, and the pension obligation bond credit rate for each fiscal year; provide amended contribution amounts for the city and employees; provide a contribution maximum for Tier A and Tier B employees; provide that the city may contribute additional monies to the retirement fund in its sole discretion; amend the modifications of contribution rates; provide guardrails with respect to the calculation of the actuarially determined contribution and incorporating the guardrails into actuarial assumptions; and amend the procedure to amend Chapter 40A?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition B, Add Preamble to City Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a preamble that declares the city to be an equitable democracy, comprised of representatives that act to make the city fair, equitable, just, and safe for all residents?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition C, Increase in Mayoral and City Council Salaries Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter III, Section 4(a) of the Dallas City Charter be amended to increase the annual salary for the mayor to $110,000 and the annual salaries for councilmembers to $90,000 with salaries subject to a yearly adjustment equal to the year-over-year percentage increase in the local consumer price index, effective January 1, 2025?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition D, Change to City Council Elections Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter IV, Section 3 of the Dallas City Charter be amended by deleting the requirement that elections for members of the city council be held in May and instead be held according to state law and as designated by city resolution or ordinance?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition E, Mayoral and City Council Term Limits Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter III, Section 3A of the Dallas City Charter be amended to eliminate the ability for members of the city council to run for city council again after serving the maximum four two-year terms and to eliminate the ability for the mayor to run for mayor again after serving the maximum two four-year terms?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition F, Require City Council to Provide Employees to City Secretary and Auditor Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter IIIA, Section 2 and Chapter IX, Section 2 of the Dallas City Charter, which requires the city council to provide assistants to the city secretary and city auditor, be amended to also require the city council to provide employees to the city secretary and city auditor?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition G, Add Eligibility Requirements for Redistricting Commission Members Charter Amendment (November 2024)
“Shall Chapter IV, Section 5(b)(2) of the Dallas City Charter, which establishes the redistricting commission, be amended by adding eligibility criteria for serving on the redistricting commission?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition H, Changes to Requirements for City Board and Commission Members Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter IV, Section 5; Chapter XV, Section 3; Chapter XVI, Section 1; and Chapter XVII, Section 2 of the Dallas City Charter be amended by eliminating the requirement that members of the redistricting commission, city plan commission, civil service board, and park and recreation board be registered to vote, qualified voters, or qualified taxpaying citizens?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition I, Changes to Local Initiative and Referendum Process Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter XVIII, Section 11 of the Dallas City Charter, which establishes procedures for initiative and referendum of ordinances, be amended to extend the deadline petitioners must meet to collect required signatures from 60 days to 120 days and reduce the number of signatures required on a petition from 10 percent of the qualified voters of the City of Dallas to five percent?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition J, Changes to City Council Appointments to Boards and Commissions Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter XXIV, Section 17(b) of the Dallas City Charter be amended to allow city council’s appointments to city boards and commissions to be replaced by city council prior to completion of a member’s two-year term?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition L, Establish Office of Inspector General Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter XI, Section 2 be amended and a new chapter be added to the Dallas City Charter that establishes the Office of the Inspector General with the Inspector General being appointed by city council and lists the duties of the Inspector General?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition O, Associate Municipal Judges Terms and Assignments Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter VIII, Section 6 of the Dallas City Charter be amended to clarify the terms of associate municipal judges and state that associate municipal judges are appointed by city council, receive assignments from the administrative judge or the administrative judge’s designee, and must be residents of Dallas within four months of the date of appointment and practicing attorneys in good standing?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition P, Remove Cost of Appeal Hearing for City Employees Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter XVI, Section 12.1 of the Dallas City Charter be amended by deleting the requirement that a city employee who appeals his or her discharge or reduction in grade to an administrative law judge pay one-half of the costs attributed to having the administrative law judge conduct the appeal hearing?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition Q, Technical Corrections to Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter III, Section 3; Chapter III, Section 4; Chapter III, Chapter 8(b); Chapter III, Section 13(a); Chapter III, Section 19; Chapter IV, Section 6(a); Chapter IV, Section 6(c)(2); Chapter IV, Section 13; Chapter XI, Section 1; Chapter XI, Section 3; Chapter XII, Section 4; Chapter XIII, Section 2(2); Chapter XIII, Section 9; Chapter XIV, Section 8; Chapter XV, Section 3; Chapter XV, Section 4; Chapter XVI, Section 3(b)(1); Chapter XVI, Section 7; Chapter XVI, Section 10(a); Chapter XVI, Section 11(b); Chapter XVIII, Section 7; Chapter XVIII, Section 11(1); Chapter XVIII, Section 15; Chapter XIX, Section 7; Chapter XXII, Section 2; Chapter XXII, Section 3; Chapter XXII, Section 4(1); Chapter XXII, Section 10; and Chapter XXIV of the Dallas City Charter be amended to conform to state law, conform to the city code, match actual practices, correct terms, clarify language, and other technical amendments?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition R, Marijuana Decriminalization Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new section in Chapter XXIV that reforms marijuana possession enforcement by prohibiting the Dallas Police Department from making arrests or issuing citations for marijuana possession or considering the odor of marijuana as probable cause for search or seizure, except as part of a violent felony or high priority narcotics felony investigation; making enforcement of Class A (currently, two to four ounces) and Class B (currently, up to two ounces) misdemeanor marijuana possession the Dallas Police Department’s lowest enforcement priority; and prohibiting city funds or personnel from being used to test cannabis-related substances to determine whether a substance meets the legal definition of marijuana, except in limited circumstances?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition S, Grants Citizens Standing to Bring Lawsuits Against the City Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new chapter that grants standing to any resident of Dallas to bring a lawsuit against the city to require the city to comply with provisions of the city charter, city ordinances, and state law; entitles claimants to seek declaratory and injunctive relief against the city and recover costs and reasonable attorney’s fees; and waives the city’s governmental immunity from suit and liability in claims brought under this amendment?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition T, Require Annual Community Survey Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter VI of the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new section compelling the city to conduct the city-commissioned Community Survey on an annual basis, to be completed by a minimum of 1,400 Dallas residents on their satisfaction on quality of life issues, the results of which will result in the city manager earning additional performance compensation (between 0 percent and 100 percent of the city manager’s annual base salary) or the termination of the city manager?”
## Dallas, Texas, Proposition U, Increased Funding and Hiring for Dallas Police Department Charter Amendment (November 2024)

“Shall Chapter XI of the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new section compelling city council to appropriate no less than 50 percent of annual revenue that exceeds the total annual revenue of the previous year to fund the Dallas Police and Fire Pension, with any monies remaining of that 50% to be appropriated to increasing the starting compensation of officers of the Dallas Police Department and to increase the number of police officers to a minimum of 4,000, and to maintain that ratio of officers to the City of Dallas population as of the date of passage of this amendment?”

**This ballot is more complex than 93 percent of U.S. Ballots.**

[{""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition A, Changes to City Employee Retirement Fund Measure (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""A"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter 40A of the Dallas City Code, known as the employees\u2019 retirement fund of the City of Dallas, be amended in accordance with Ordinance No. 32801 to: add, revise, and delete various definitions; provide amended terms and term limits of the board; modify the retirement fund board\u2019s powers and duties; specify the date the board shall adopt the actuarially determined contribution rate, the current total adjusted total obligation rate, the current total obligation rate, and the pension obligation bond credit rate for each fiscal year; provide amended contribution amounts for the city and employees; provide a contribution maximum for Tier A and Tier B employees; provide that the city may contribute additional monies to the retirement fund in its sole discretion; amend the modifications of contribution rates; provide guardrails with respect to the calculation of the actuarially determined contribution and incorporating the guardrails into actuarial assumptions; and amend the procedure to amend Chapter 40A?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition B, Add Preamble to City Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""B"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a preamble that declares the city to be an equitable democracy, comprised of representatives that act to make the city fair, equitable, just, and safe for all residents?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition C, Increase in Mayoral and City Council Salaries Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""C"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter III, Section 4(a) of the Dallas City Charter be amended to increase the annual salary for the mayor to $110,000 and the annual salaries for councilmembers to $90,000 with salaries subject to a yearly adjustment equal to the year-over-year percentage increase in the local consumer price index, effective January 1, 2025?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition D, Change to City Council Elections Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""D"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter IV, Section 3 of the Dallas City Charter be amended by deleting the requirement that elections for members of the city council be held in May and instead be held according to state law and as designated by city resolution or ordinance?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition E, Mayoral and City Council Term Limits Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""E"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter III, Section 3A of the Dallas City Charter be amended to eliminate the ability for members of the city council to run for city council again after serving the maximum four two-year terms and to eliminate the ability for the mayor to run for mayor again after serving the maximum two four-year terms?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition F, Require City Council to Provide Employees to City Secretary and Auditor Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""F"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter IIIA, Section 2 and Chapter IX, Section 2 of the Dallas City Charter, which requires the city council to provide assistants to the city secretary and city auditor, be amended to also require the city council to provide employees to the city secretary and city auditor?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition G, Add Eligibility Requirements for Redistricting Commission Members Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""G"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter IV, Section 5(b)(2) of the Dallas City Charter, which establishes the redistricting commission, be amended by adding eligibility criteria for serving on the redistricting commission?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition H, Changes to Requirements for City Board and Commission Members Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""H"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter IV, Section 5; Chapter XV, Section 3; Chapter XVI, Section 1; and Chapter XVII, Section 2 of the Dallas City Charter be amended by eliminating the requirement that members of the redistricting commission, city plan commission, civil service board, and park and recreation board be registered to vote, qualified voters, or qualified taxpaying citizens?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition I, Changes to Local Initiative and Referendum Process Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""I"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter XVIII, Section 11 of the Dallas City Charter, which establishes procedures for initiative and referendum of ordinances, be amended to extend the deadline petitioners must meet to collect required signatures from 60 days to 120 days and reduce the number of signatures required on a petition from 10 percent of the qualified voters of the City of Dallas to five percent?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition J, Changes to City Council Appointments to Boards and Commissions Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""J"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter XXIV, Section 17(b) of the Dallas City Charter be amended to allow city council\u2019s appointments to city boards and commissions to be replaced by city council prior to completion of a member\u2019s two-year term?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition L, Establish Office of Inspector General Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""L"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter XI, Section 2 be amended and a new chapter be added to the Dallas City Charter that establishes the Office of the Inspector General with the Inspector General being appointed by city council and lists the duties of the Inspector General?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition O, Associate Municipal Judges Terms and Assignments Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""O"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter VIII, Section 6 of the Dallas City Charter be amended to clarify the terms of associate municipal judges and state that associate municipal judges are appointed by city council, receive assignments from the administrative judge or the administrative judge\u2019s designee, and must be residents of Dallas within four months of the date of appointment and practicing attorneys in good standing?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition P, Remove Cost of Appeal Hearing for City Employees Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""P"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter XVI, Section 12.1 of the Dallas City Charter be amended by deleting the requirement that a city employee who appeals his or her discharge or reduction in grade to an administrative law judge pay one-half of the costs attributed to having the administrative law judge conduct the appeal hearing?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition Q, Technical Corrections to Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""Q"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter III, Section 3; Chapter III, Section 4; Chapter III, Chapter 8(b); Chapter III, Section 13(a); Chapter III, Section 19; Chapter IV, Section 6(a); Chapter IV, Section 6(c)(2); Chapter IV, Section 13; Chapter XI, Section 1; Chapter XI, Section 3; Chapter XII, Section 4; Chapter XIII, Section 2(2); Chapter XIII, Section 9; Chapter XIV, Section 8; Chapter XV, Section 3; Chapter XV, Section 4; Chapter XVI, Section 3(b)(1); Chapter XVI, Section 7; Chapter XVI, Section 10(a); Chapter XVI, Section 11(b); Chapter XVIII, Section 7; Chapter XVIII, Section 11(1); Chapter XVIII, Section 15; Chapter XIX, Section 7; Chapter XXII, Section 2; Chapter XXII, Section 3; Chapter XXII, Section 4(1); Chapter XXII, Section 10; and Chapter XXIV of the Dallas City Charter be amended to conform to state law, conform to the city code, match actual practices, correct terms, clarify language, and other technical amendments?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition R, Marijuana Decriminalization Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""R"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new section in Chapter XXIV that reforms marijuana possession enforcement by prohibiting the Dallas Police Department from making arrests or issuing citations for marijuana possession or considering the odor of marijuana as probable cause for search or seizure, except as part of a violent felony or high priority narcotics felony investigation; making enforcement of Class A (currently, two to four ounces) and Class B (currently, up to two ounces) misdemeanor marijuana possession the Dallas Police Department\u2019s lowest enforcement priority; and prohibiting city funds or personnel from being used to test cannabis-related substances to determine whether a substance meets the legal definition of marijuana, except in limited circumstances?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition S, Grants Citizens Standing to Bring Lawsuits Against the City Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""S"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new chapter that grants standing to any resident of Dallas to bring a lawsuit against the city to require the city to comply with provisions of the city charter, city ordinances, and state law; entitles claimants to seek declaratory and injunctive relief against the city and recover costs and reasonable attorney\u2019s fees; and waives the city\u2019s governmental immunity from suit and liability in claims brought under this amendment?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition T, Require Annual Community Survey Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""T"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter VI of the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new section compelling the city to conduct the city-commissioned Community Survey on an annual basis, to be completed by a minimum of 1,400 Dallas residents on their satisfaction on quality of life issues, the results of which will result in the city manager earning additional performance compensation (between 0 percent and 100 percent of the city manager\u2019s annual base salary) or the termination of the city manager?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}, {""title"": ""Dallas, Texas, Proposition U, Increased Funding and Hiring for Dallas Police Department Charter Amendment (November 2024)"", ""propositionId"": ""U"", ""fullText"": ""\u201cShall Chapter XI of the Dallas City Charter be amended by adding a new section compelling city council to appropriate no less than 50 percent of annual revenue that exceeds the total annual revenue of the previous year to fund the Dallas Police and Fire Pension, with any monies remaining of that 50% to be appropriated to increasing the starting compensation of officers of the Dallas Police Department and to increase the number of police officers to a minimum of 4,000, and to maintain that ratio of officers to the City of Dallas population as of the date of passage of this amendment?\u201d"", ""type"": ""Ballot Measure"", ""level"": ""City-town""}]}"
